University of Warsaw's Dominance in ACM ICPC | Generated by AI

Home 2025.10

The University of Warsaw has an outstanding record in the ACM International Collegiate Programming Contest (ICPC), consistently ranking among the world’s top universities in this prestigious competition. Here’s a summary of their performance based on available information:

  • World Championships: The University of Warsaw has won the ACM ICPC World Finals twice, in 2003 and 2007, making it one of the few universities to achieve this feat.
  • Consistent Participation: Since 1994, the University of Warsaw has qualified for the World Finals every year, holding a record for uninterrupted participation. This demonstrates their sustained excellence in competitive programming.
  • Medal Record: The university’s teams, often referred to as the “Warsaw Eagles,” have secured multiple medals at the World Finals:
    • Gold Medals: In addition to their championship wins in 2003 and 2007, they won gold medals in 2017 (2nd place) and 2019 (4th place).
    • Silver Medals: They earned a silver medal in 2016.
    • Other Notable Finishes: The team has consistently placed high, such as 2nd place in the 2012 World Finals hosted by Warsaw itself, and 4th place in 2019.
  • Regional Dominance: The University of Warsaw frequently excels in the Central Europe Regional Contest, often securing top positions. For example, they won the regional contest in 2015 and 2016, and placed second in 2014, qualifying for the World Finals each time.
  • Recent Performance: In the 2024 ICPC Polish Collegiate Programming Contest, a University of Warsaw team (Arkadiusz Czarkowski, Bartłomiej Czarkowski, and Tomasz Nowak) won a gold medal as the best team to solve 9 tasks, and they were also the 2024 ICPC Europe Champions. Other UW teams secured silver and bronze medals in the same contest.
  • Global Recognition: A post on X highlighted that the University of Warsaw has outperformed even Harvard in terms of the number of students qualifying for the ICPC World Finals, with Polish teams consistently reaching the finals for 30 years.

The University of Warsaw’s success is attributed to the rigorous training of its students at the Faculty of Mathematics, Informatics, and Mechanics, under experienced coaches like Prof. Krzysztof Diks and Prof. Jan Madey, who received a Lifetime Coach Award in 2017. Their consistent qualification, frequent medal wins, and two world championships underscore their position as a global powerhouse in competitive programming.
